A comparison between single crystal surfaces and supported catalysts E. Boe11Od1, R.J. Vreeburg, O.L.J. Gijzeman, J.W. Geus* Utrecht University, Department of Inorganic Chemistry, P.O. Box 80083, 3508 TB Utrecht, Netherlands Received 8 April 1993; revised 5 January 1994; accepted 8 April 1994 Abstract The interaction of carbon monoxide with nickel-iron alloys is studied on Ni (111)-Fe surfaces by means of ellipsometry and Auger electron spectroscopy, and by means of infrared spectroscopy on y-A1203-supported NixFe catalysts. The nickel-to-iron ratio of the alloy strongly affects the interaction with CO. On alloys with an iron atom fraction of 0.3 or less the adsorption of CO is molecular, whereas at fractions higher than 0.4 it is initially dissociative. Surfaces contaminated with carbon and oxygen exhibit a lower heat of adsorption. The presence of pre-adsorbed hydrogen lowers the amount of CO which can be adsorbed on Ni (111)-Fe surfaces, whereas on supported catalysts it leads to the formation of fotmate species already at room temperature. Keywords: Alloys; Carbon monoxide; Crystal surface; Iron; Nickel; Supported catalysts 1. Introduction The accumulation of carbon in iron and nickel catalysts during Fischer-Tropsch synthesis strongly determines the activity and selectivity. Carbon deposits of amorphous, carbidic or graphitic nature result in a decreased activity, whereas the occurrence of filamentous carbon leads to an inadmissible pressure drop over the reactor bed. Therefore, suppression of carbon deposition on Fischer-Tropsch catalysts is highly desirable. Since the deposited carbon originates from CO dissociated on the metal surface, the interaction of CO with single crystal surfaces of pure iron ( bcc ) and pure nickel ( fcc ) has been extensively studied [ 1 -6] . From these studies *Corresponding author. Boellaard et al. /Journal of Molecular Catalysis 92 (1994) 299-310 it is concluded that the different behaviour of iron and nickel catalysts in the FischerTropsch synthesis is related to the different interaction of CO with both metal surfaces. Alloying an active metal with a second ( in) active metal can change the catalytic performance drastically. Control of the carbon accumulation in Fischer-Tropsch catalysts during synthesis may therefore be achieved by using nickel-iron alloys. This paper covers studies on Ni(111)-Fe single crystals and supported NiXFe/ A1203 catalysts. Since Ni(111) has an intrinsic low activity for CO dissociation [6] , this surface was selected as the basis for a series of in situ prepared Ni(111)Fe surface alloys. For the supported nickel-iron catalysts a special preparation technique was used which ensures a uniform composition of the bimetallic particles. First the CO interaction with Ni(111)-Fe surfaces will be described and subsequently the interaction with the supported NiFe/A1203 catalysts. Finally a comparison between both systems will be made. 2. Experimental 2.1. Ni(111)-Fe surfaces All single-crystal experiments were performed in a standard UHV system equipped with facilities for argon-ion bombardment, Auger electron spectroscopy (AES ) , low energy electron diffraction ( LEED ) , and ellipsometry [ 7 ] . The Ni(111)-Fe surfaces were prepared by means of thermal decomposition of Fe ( CO ) 5 on a Ni (111) crystal [ 8 ] . The last step in the preparation procedure of the surface alloys was a reduction of the oxidized surfaces by hydrogen at 625 K. The average atom fraction of iron in the surface alloy XL,Fe was calculated from the measured low energy Auger peaks of iron (47 eV) and nickel (61 eV). All Ni (111)-Fe surfaces studied had an iron atom fraction of 0 <_ XL,Fe <_ 0.5. The carbon and oxygen coverage of all clean surfaces, as calculated from the Auger peaks at 272 eV and 515 eV, respectively, were less than 0.02 of a monolayer. LEED observations on all clean Ni (111)-Fe surfaces revealed the unchanged hexagonal (1 X 1) pattern of pure Ni (111) . Ellipsometry was used to monitor the adsorption of CO ( 99.997% ) . The ellipsometric parameter 8d was supposed to vary linearly with the amount of molecularly adsorbed CO [ 2 ] . CO adsorption isotherms were measured by determining the saturation value of 8d after a stepwise increase of the CO pressure up to 10-' Pa and a subsequent stepwise decrease to 10-6 Pa at a constant temperature in the range of 300-525 K. Before and after CO exposure the composition of the surface was checked with AES at a base pressure of 10-8 Pa. 2.2. NixFe%11203 catalysts The nickel-iron catalysts were prepared by means of homogeneous depositionprecipitation of complex iron cyanides with a nickel salt onto a y-A1203 support. E. Boellaard et al. /Journal of Molecular Catalysis 92 (1994) 299-310 301 By using selected iron cyanide complexes, the nickel-to-iron ratio in the catalyst precursors could be established at three discrete values, viz., 2.0, 1.5 and 1.0, which corresponds with iron atom fractions of 0.33, 0.40 and 0.50. The resulting catalysts, which had a metal loading of 20 wt%, will be denoted Ni2Fe, Ni3Fe2 and NiFe, respectively. The general features of the preparation method have been described extensively [9]. Before being used as catalysts in the Fischer-Tropsch synthesis, the cyanide precursors were oxidized and subsequently reduced. A detailed analysis of the Ni2Fe catalyst during these activation treatments has been performed by means of magnetic methods and Mossbauer spectroscopy [ 10] . The surface of the reduced catalysts was monitored by transmission infrared spectroscopy of adsorbed carbon monoxide probe molecules in equipment which permits in situ recording of spectra. Catalyst samples were prepared by pressing the ground cyanide precursor to a self-supporting wafer. After oxidation in a flow of helium containing 1 vol% of oxygen and reduction in a flow of 10 vol% hydrogen in argon at temperatures up to 723 K, infrared spectroscopic measurements were performed according to the following procedure: After cooling down to room temperature, the flow was stopped and the gas was removed by evacuating the system for 1.8 ks (1 ks =103 seconds) to a pressure of 10-4 Pa. Subsequently, the first (reference) spectrum was recorded in the spectral range of 4000-1000 cm-1 with a maximum resolution of 5.3 cm-'. Next, 1.33 kPa of carbon monoxide (99.997%) was introduced and a second scan of the infrared spectrum was started. Additional infrared scans were performed at 0.4, 0.9, 1.8, 3.6, 7.2, and 10.8 ks after the initial carbon monoxide dose. Finally the cell was reconnected to the vacuum system and desorption of adsorbed carbon monoxide was followed by repeated scans according to the above mentioned time sequence. Infrared absorption spectra of CO molecules bonded to the catalyst surface were obtained by computer substraction of the reference spectrum from the spectrum of interest. 3. Results 3.1. A reversible change of 8d with the CO pressure was not observed for a Ni (111)-Fe surface with XL,Fe = 0.39. Interaction of CO with Ni(111)-Fe surfaces From the results represented in Fig. 1 and Table 1 it is evident that the interaction of CO with Ni(111)-Fe surfaces within two discrete composition regions of the alloy surface is different. On Ni (111)-Fe surfaces with XL,Fe _< 0.26, the CO adsorption is completely reversible. The reversible adsorption is attributed to molecularly adsorbed CO. The isosteric heat of adsorption for thus adsorbed CO is 106 t 5 kJ/ mol and does not depend on the XL,Fe and the CO coverage. For Ni (111)-Fe surfaces with XL,Fe >_ 0.40, however, CO dissociates initially at temperatures above 420 K. Equal amounts of carbon and oxygen are present on the Ni(111)-Fe surface after dissociation as can be seen in Table 1. Further adsorption of CO on this surface is reversible; the isosteric heat of adsorption is lowered by the presence of carbon and oxygen at the surface. Immediately after preparation of the Ni(111)-Fe surfaces, less CO could be adsorbed at 300 K than after annealing of the surface at 475 K. Since the experimental data obtained do not indicate a change in surface composition or structure, E. Boellaard et al. /Journal of Molecular Catalysis 92 (1994) 299-310 307 the difference in CO chemisorption is ascribed to the presence of adsorbed hydrogen on the surface after reduction, but before annealing in vacuo at 475 K. Since hydrogen was difficult to evacuate from the UHV system, the Ni(111)-Fe surfaces were always exposed to hydrogen at 300 K for a period of time after the reduction. Upon annealing the surface at 475 K, this adsorbed hydrogen will desorb from the surface and a clean Ni(111)-Fe surface results onto which CO can adsorb. The adsorption of CO on hydrogen precovered nickel surfaces leads to partial displacement of hydrogen. Interaction of CO with the remaining hydrogen was revealed by TPD experiments [ 12]. 4.2. Interaction of CO with supported NixFelAlZ03 catalysts Admission of carbon monoxide to the reduced Ni2Fe catalyst results in a number of differently adsorbed CO species as evident from the IR spectra. The sharp absorption band at 1978-1982 cm-' can be assigned to CO species which are linearly bonded to the metallic alloy surface [ 13 ] . The increase of the wavenumber can be explained by occupation of different sites or adsorbate-adsorbate interaction at increasing CO coverages. Adsorption sites which are made up of metallic surface atoms which are adjacent to charged metal atoms may account for the weak band at 2032 cm-'. It is difficult to completely reduce the Fe and Ni atoms to the metallic state. Some Fe(II) may be stabilized at the interface with the alumina support. CO molecules adsorbed at the perimeter with the support may give rise to the weak absorption at 2032 cm-' [10]. Absorption bands in the range 1950-1625 cm-' are interpreted as arising from bridged-bonded species [ 13 ] . On the nickel-iron alloy a number of different adsorption geometries exist, which leads to poorly resolved absorption bands. Upon prolonged exposure the band becomes more structured indicating the existence of some discrete sites. The shift of the 1870 cm-' band to 1900 cm-' indicates that the strength of adsorption for the finally adsorbed CO species is lower than for the CO species initially adsorbed. The carbon monoxide admitted not only adsorbs on the catalyst surface, but also reacts to formate, as evidenced by the bands at 1601 and 1351 cm-'. These bands arise from the asymmetric and symmetric OCO stretching vibrations of the carboxylate group. The in-plane-bending of the CH bond makes up a composite band at 1351 cm-', while the stretching vibration of the CH bond is represented by either the 2761 or the 2674 cm -' band. The remaining band might represent a combination band involving a stretch vibration of OCO and a CH deformation [ 14,15 ] . As compared to the vibrations of formic acid in the gas phase or formic acid adsorbed on A1203, the present bands are observed at significant lower frequencies [ 16] . This observation and the fact that reaction occurs already at 300 K, provide strong evidence that the formate is formed and adsorbed on the metal surface. Since no hydrogen is admitted during the IR experiment, the H atoms involved in the formate formation must originate from the reduction treatment. Apparently, evacuation at room temperature is not sufficient to remove the hydrogen from the 308 E. Boellaard et al. /Journal of Molecular Catalysis 92 (1994) 299-310 metallic alloy surface. When the surface is covered by hydrogen, the admitted carbon monoxide either displaces the hydrogen to facilitate adsorption, or reacts with the hydrogen to formate. The adsorption and the reaction also account for the increase of the absorbance in the range 2000-1625 cm-', and subsequently of the formate bands, with time. Formate formation from CO implies residual carbon remaining on the catalyst surface or reacting with adsorbed hydrogen to CH species. The weak absorption at 2944 cm-', which is in the range of the aliphatic CH stretch vibrations, nicely supports this interpretation. In addition to formate some water is produced by the catalyst as indicated by the broad band around 3450 cm-'. Upon evacuation of the system, the CO species, which were adsorbed upon prolonged carbon monoxide exposure and which caused the absorption bands to shift to higher wavenumbers, desorb. The low frequency species remain bonded. Evacuation does not affect the formate species. For the Ni3Fe2 and NiFe catalysts the major band at 2038 and 2043 cm-1, respectively, is assigned to linearly adsorbed CO. With respect to the Ni2Fe catalyst the high wavenumbers suggest that the adsorption sites are perturbed by adjacent charged metal atoms. Since bridged-bonded CO requires ensembles of reduced metal atoms, the observed small fraction of CO in the bridged adsorption mode also indicates a contaminated surface layer. Contamination of the reduced alloy surface can be caused by initial dissociative adsorption of CO upon admission. The absorbance remains constant in time and no formate species could be detected. The absence of formate species suggests that this oxygenate will be formed at 300 K only if bridged-bonded CO together with hydrogen are present on the catalyst surface. Upon evacuation of the system the adsorbed CO remains bonded to the catalyst surface. 4.3. Comparison between Ni(Il l )-Fe surfaces and NixFe%11203 catalysts From the presented results on Ni(111)-Fe surfaces and NiFe/A1203 catalysts, it is obvious that the interaction of carbon monoxide with the two nickel-iron alloy systems resemble each other closely. For both systems the interaction strongly depends on the fraction of iron in the metallic alloy. On NiFe/A1203 catalysts and Ni(111)-Fe surfaces of an iron atom fraction less than 0.3, no CO dissociation proceeds, whereas on systems with an iron atom fraction exceeding 0.4, CO initially dissociates. The presence of carbon and oxygen on the nickel-iron surface leads in both systems to a decrease of the strength of the interaction of additional molecularly adsorbed CO, as is evident from a decrease of the heat of adsorption and an increase of the wavenumber of adsorbed CO. The discrepancy in the temperature at which CO dissociation is observed on the NiFe/A1203 catalysts and on Ni(111)-Fe surfaces, viz., 300 and 420 K, respectively, can be explained by the 109 to 104 times lower CO pressures used in the latter experiments. The very slow desorption of CO from the Ni (111)-Fe surfaces at 300 K prohibits measurement of the desorption branch of an adsorption-desorption curve, but E. Boellaard et al. /Journal of Molecular Catalysis 92 (1994) 299-310 309 facilitates the recording of 1R spectraupon evacuation of the Ni.,Fe/A1203 catalysts. In both systems the adsorption of CO indicates the presence of residual hydrogen adsorbed on the alloy surface. Since the presence of hydrogen cannot be assessed by the analytical techniques used, unequivocal verification of the presence of adsorbed hydrogen calls for additional study, for instance, temperature-programmed desorption experiments. The observed uniform behaviour of the nickel-iron systems towards the interaction with CO leads to the conclusion that a study of Ni(111)-Fe surfaces under UHV conditions can provide very valuable information about the behaviour of supported Ni,,Fe/A1203 catalysts under atmospheric pressures. The fact that the Ni(111)-Fe surfaces do predict the behaviour of the Ni,,Fe/A1203 catalysts so well, might partly be due to the moderately small size of the alloy particles. The alloy particles in the catalysts are about 30 nm in diameter. Metal particles of this size are likely to expose the most densely packed crystallographic planes, which in this case is the fcc (111) plane. This is exactly the Ni(111)-Fe surface plane used in the UHV study. 5. Conclusions The dissociation of CO on Ni,,Fe/A1203 catalysts agrees very well with that on monocrystalline Ni(111)-Fe surfaces. On both nickel-iron systems two discrete composition regions can be distinguished. No CO dissociation proceeds on surfaces with an iron atom fraction of 0.3 or less, whereas CO dissociates initially on surfaces of an iron atom fraction of 0.4 or higher. The presence of carbon and oxygen on the surface after CO dissociation lowers the heat of adsorption for further adsorbed CO on monocrystalline alloy surfaces and the back donation to molecularly bonded CO on supported alloy particles. The metallic nickel-iron alloys are likely to exhibit strong adsorption of hydrogen. The catalyst with an iron atom fraction of 0.3 displays already at 300 K a high activity for the reaction of carbon monoxide to formate. References [ 1 ] T.J. Vink, O.L.J. Gijzeman and J.W. The observed uniform behaviour of the nickel-iron systems towards the interaction with CO leads to the conclusion that a study of Ni(111)-Fe surfaces under UHV conditions can provide very valuable information about the behaviour of supported Ni,,Fe/A1203 catalysts under atmospheric pressures. The fact that the Ni(111)-Fe surfaces do predict the behaviour of the Ni,,Fe/A1203 catalysts so well, might partly be due to the moderately small size of the alloy particles. The alloy particles in the catalysts are about 30 nm in diameter. Metal particles of this size are likely to expose the most densely packed crystallographic planes, which in this case is the fcc (111) plane. This is exactly the Ni(111)-Fe surface plane used in the UHV study. 5. The interaction of carbon monoxide with nickel—iron alloys is studied on Ni(111)-Fe surfaces by means of ellipsometry and Auger electron spectroscopy, and by means of infrared spectroscopy on γ-Al2O3-supported Ni x Fe catalysts. The nickel-to-iron ratio of the alloy strongly affects the interaction with CO. On alloys with an iron atom fraction of 0.3 or less the adsorption of CO is molecular, whereas at fractions higher than 0.4 it is initially dissociative. Surfaces contaminated with carbon and oxygen exhibit a lower heat of adsorption. The presence of pre-adsorbed hydrogen lowers the amount of CO which can be adsorbed on Ni(111)-Fe surfaces, whereas on supported catalysts it leads to the formation of formate species already at room temperature.
